spell.name: Witch Bolt
entries: You temporaliy infuse yourself with the ability to release beams of crackling, blue energy. As an action, you can lance this energy out toward a creature within range, forming a sustained arc of lightning between you and the target. Make a ranged spell attack against that creature. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d12} lightning damage, and is bonded with you. You can be bonded to only one target at a time. If you bond yourself to a new target, the first one ends.

You can use your bonus action to deal {@damage 1d12} lightning damage to the bonded target automatically as long as you have a free hand or are holding a spellcasting focus, and the bonded target is within range and it doesn't have total cover from you.
The bond ends if you use your bonus action to do anything else.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the initial damage increases by {@scaledamage 1d12|2-9|1d12} for each slot level above 2nd.

trait.name: Frosty Presence
entries: The Siugȃk doesn't generate heat and it cools the surrounding area to below freezing temperatures. As an action, the Siugȃk can expell a chilly blast which freezes the surrounding area, turning the air within 5 feet into solid snow.

trait.name: Humanoid Infestation
entries: As an action, the Siugȃk can infest a humanoid corpse within it's reach. The process takes one minute, after which the Siugȃk goes inside and takes over control of the target's body. The Siugȃk retains its Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores inside the target's body, and prevents the body from decay. It otherwise adopts the target's statistics and abilities.

action.name: Pincer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage. On a hit, the Siugȃk is attached to the creature and can't make further pincer attacks until it lets go (no action required), or is removed with a {@dc 11} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

action.name: Lamprey Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage. On a hit, the creature must make a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or have their Constitution score reduced by {@dice 1d4}. The target dies if this reduces its Constitution to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest.

trait.name: Frost Camouflage
entries: The Qinauk has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The Qinanuk has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the Qinanuk's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Keen Bloodthirst
entries: The Qinanuk has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) and Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to see and track humanoids.

trait.name: Ethereal Jaunt
entries: As a bonus action, the true can magically shift from the Material Plane to the Ethereal Plane, or vice versa.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Lashing Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or take 14 ({@damage 4d6}) necrotic damage and have their hit point maximum reduced by the same amount.

monster.name: Uvinnik

trait.name: Nightmare Being
entries: When the Uvinnik dies, it dissolves into the ground leaving only the deer skull behind. Any humanoid that sees this deer skull must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure they are {@condition frightened} of it, failing by 5 or more causes them to be compelled to put it on their head. If a humanoid puts the deer skull on their head, the Uvinnik will attempt to take over the target's body, forcing them to make a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw. If they fail this save, the humanoid instantly dies with the Uvinnik reforming from the corpse.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the Uvinnik fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Uvinnik makes 2 melee attacks.

action.name: Rending Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, they must make a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or become {@condition grappled}.

action.name: Horrifying Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d10 + 6}) poison damage. On a hit, the target must make a {@dc 18} Constitution throw or become {@condition poisoned}. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Gaze of Death {@recharge}
entries: The Uvinnik turns its gaze towards one creature it can see within 60 feet. The target must make a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, target becomes {@condition paralyzed} until the end of the Uvinnik's next turn and takes 26 ({@damage 4d12}) psychic damage, or half as much damage and not becoming {@condition paralyzed} on a successful one.

action.name: Soul Rend (1/day)
entries: The Uvinnik attempts to pull the soul from a creature it has {@condition grappled}. The creature must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature is reduced to 0 hit points. On a success, the creature takes 20 ({@damage 6d6}) necrotic damage.

legendaryHeader: The Uvinnik can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of a creature's turn. The Uvinnik regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Maul
entries: The Uvinnik makes a rending claw or horrifying bite attack.

legendary.name: Soul Purge (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: The Uvinnik draws in the souls of any dead creatures in the area, regaining 36 ({@damage 8d8}) hit points.

This... thing, stands about 15 feet tall, and very vaguely resembles something humanoid, but it's no longer anything close. The head of this creature, some unholy cross between that of a bear, snake and deer. A large powerful maw like that of a bear, with rows of horrifying rending tendrils that form teeth, a jaw able to become unhinged beyond a fathomable extent, two large empty sockets where eyes should be, large antlers that seem to extend another 5 feet on the top of the head. While it has no eyes, it seems to be able to see just fine, and if it has you in its sight, you will feel a cold run through your body worse than any blizzard could force upon you. The chest of the beast is a skeletal form with patched up human flesh covering a large amount of it. The skin of it is far more resistance that one would expect as it is incredibly calcified and molded into the bones of the creature. The arms of it are impossibly long, giving it what seems like a 20 foot reach, they are covered with what seems like a cross between wolf fur and hardened bone, and it feels like a solidified knotted fur. The hands and feets of it are completely skeletal, vaguely humanlike hands, with claws at the end of each of the 5 fingers that seen to be near 4 inches long. The legs of the beast seem to be more inline with something like a deer, long and almost graceful in a way, if they weren't riddled with the same grotesque matted fur-flesh as the arms.

entries.name: From Humanity It Falls
entries: Many rumors plague the north regions of every world of a being of nightmares that devours human flesh which was once human itself. The Uvinnik is a creature of ancient druidic lore, said to be born of human that would eat flesh of many things, wolves, deers, bear, and most importantly to complete it's transformation, human.

entries.name: Druid's Bane
entries: Many archdruids have tried to destroy these things, or at least contain them, using any means necessary, as they hold sway unfathomable to most sane people. The unnatural presence of these creatures results in an irrational hatred between any druids and Uvinnik. The Uvinnik vastly prefer to devour anyone versed in druidic magic over anything else.

entries.name: Consequences Of One's Birth
entries: Once a Uvinnik is formed, they begin to destroy local wildlife to amass bodies which will it will use to create {@creature Qinanuk|VauxsDiscordHomebrewExtravaganza|Qinanuks} or {@creature Siguâk|VauxsDiscordHomebrewExtravaganza|Siguâks}, anything it can't use for either, it will attach to itself, resulting in the disgusting amalgamation of furs on it's body. They can strip an entire forests clear of any and all animal life within days.

entries.name: Humanoid Fixation
entries: It will target any humanoids it finds, hunting them until they collapse, with the only exception being any humanoid it would have recognized as family, which it will almost ritualistically guard. The Uvinnik's lairs are generally former homes of the family, or in rarer cases, caves or even a glacier if they had no former home.

trait.name: Limbo
entries: The Harrowing is in constant flux. At the beginning of its turn, roll one of the following damage types at random.
The Harrowing gains immunity to that damage type and its Tendril attacks deal that damage type until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Tendril
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) of the Harrowing's damage type.

legendary.name: Spawn
entries: The Harrowing spawns a {@creature callous critter|VauxsDiscordHomebrewExtravaganza} within 5 ft. range.

legendary.name: Tendril Attack
entries: The Harrowing makes a tendril attack.

legendary.name: Flail (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Harrowing flails its tendrils in a 15 ft. radius around it. Every creature in this radius must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 2d8 + 6} of the Harrowing's current damage type and be knocked {@condition prone}. One a successful save, they take half as much damage and are not knocked {@condition prone}.

reaction.name: Constrict
entries: When a Large or smaller creature is hit by the Harrowings tendril attack, the Harrowing can attempt to grab the creature. The target must make a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or take {@dice 1d6 + 4} of the Harrowing's current damage type and be {@condition restrained}. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

trait.name: Limbo
entries: The Callous Critter is in constant flux. At the beginning of its turn, roll one of the following damage types at random.
The Callous Critter gains immunity to that damage type and its Tendril attacks deal that damage type until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Tendril
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d10}) of the current Callous Critter's damage type.

trait.name: Desert's Fury
entries: The Ii'Tliish is an embodiment of the desert, and as such is the center of a sandstorm {@dice 1d20 + 5} miles in diameter. The sandstorm causes the area to be lightly obscured, and causes disadvantage on ranged attack rolls.

trait.name: Greater Magic Resistance
entries: The Ii'Tliish has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects. Additionally, the Ii'Tliish can not be reduced below 50 HP by any spell damage, including {@spell Wish}.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (5/Day)
entries: If Ii'Tliish fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The Ii'Tliish deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Lightning Storm
entries: The Ii'Tliish releases four bolts of lightning from its wings, each of which can strike a target the Ii'Tliish can see within 240 feet of it. A target must make a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw, taking 28 ({@damage 5d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Sand Storm
entries: The Ii'Tliish flaps its wings, causing the sands around to swirl into a 60 foot diamater sandstorm centered on itself. Any creatures in the area other than the Ii'Tliish must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Primal Roar {@recharge 5}
entries: Ii'Tliish lets out a primal, earpiercing screech. Each creature within 120 feet of the Ii'Tliish must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw, taking 67 ({@damage 12d10}) thunder damage and becoming defeaned until the end of the Ii'Tliish's next turn on a failed save, or half as much damage and not becoming defeaned on a successful one.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the Ii'Tliish's choice that is within 240 feet of Ii'Tliish and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 24} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the Ii'Tliish's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

legendary.name: Hunt
entries: The Ii'Tliish moves up to half to its speed.

legendary.name: Claw
entries: The Ii'Tliish claws at a target within 30 feet of it, which is has {@hit +18} to hit, dealing 32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) slashing damage on a hit. If the target is a creature, they must succeed a {@dc 24} Strength saving throw or be {@condition grappled} by the Ii'Tliish.

legendary.name: Elemental Mastery (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Ii'Tliish summons a {@creature Fire Elemental Myrmidon|MTF}, {@creature Earth Elemental Myrmidon|MTF}, {@creature Air Elemental Myrmidon|MTF}, or a {@creature Fluxcharger|GGR}.

legendary.name: Crushing Tail (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Ii'Tliish slams it's tail onto the ground. Each creature within a 100 foot long, 20 foot wide line from the Ii'Tliish must succeed on a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw taking 22 ({@damage 4d6 + 10}) bludgeoning damage and have their speed reduced to 0 on a failure, or half as much damage and their remaining the same on a success.

legendary.name: Storm Rejuvination (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: The Ii'Tliish pulls in the surrounding storm clouds to fuel it's fury. The Ii'Tliish regains 55 ({@damage 10d10}) hit points.

A living resperation of nature's wrath. The Ii'Tliish's head resembles that of a blue dragon, with the telltale horn, and maw of nightmarish teeth. The eyes of the Ii'Tliish are that of white ball lightning, with the horn seemingly pulling in the surrounding electricity of the air to empower the Ii'Tliish. The body resembles that of a purple worm, with the long, winding body, several hundred feet long, covered in crackling lightning with two hind legs with powerful claws at the end of them like that of a Roc, capable of tearing entire hamlets from the map. The long tail swishes after the legs, with a freedom of movement like it has a mind of it's own, slamming around anything brave or foolish enough to get close to the Ii'Tliish. But the most defining feature of the Ii'Tliish is its wings, which are made of pure lightning, and reach from end to end to almost a mile long.

entries.name: The Fury of the Elements
entries: The Ii'Tliish is a creature born of many elements meeting, air, earth, and fire. In the primodial times from before humanity, the Ii'Tliish was born as the Elemental Planes were forming fully, and from it's birth, part of the world of Ibon was created. Ii'Tliish is a creature that holds sway over the elementals that cross the planes, following their forebearer into the Material Plane, and into the desert it has created known as the Hellish Steppes.

entries.name: A God in a Godless World
entries: The Ii'Tliish is a being that is known for being worshipped by many cults, mainly from Wagrium Confederation, and other desert regions from around the world. It is a creature known for unpredictable desruction, and reformation, attempting to destroy those that dare enter into the Hellish Steppes, and creating the vast resources that dot the same region, leading to the almost divine presence it holds in the area. People in the region pray to the Ii'Tliish for safe travels as they traverse the area, and attempt to mine the many electrically charged minerals.

entries.name: Arcana's Malediction
entries: There have been a few attempts to rid this world of the Ii'Tliish, through banishment, spells, and many other means. Banishing the creature works for a time, though it always seems to find a way back, returning to its nest within a year at most, and any attempts to bind it to other planes seem to only anger the creature, leading to a quick death for any involved. Otherwise attempting to destroy the creature through spells seems to work until the Ii'Tliish reaches a state of magical stasis, becoming almost immune to magic. Few have been rumored to have seen such stasis, though none have been able to tell the tale of what comes from it.

entries.name: The Nest of Lightning
entries: The Ii'Tliish's nest is rumored to be a giant stormcloud in the center of the Hellish Steppes. No longer does anyone dare approach it, for those that do, are met with the full force of the Desert's Fury, and none have returned after.

legendaryGroup.name: Uvinnik
lairActions: When fighting inside its lair, the Uvinnik can invoke the ambient magic to take lair actions. On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the Uvinnik takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the Uvinnik can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: Summon a {@creature Qinanuk|VauxsDiscordHomebrewExtravaganza} (it rolls it's own inititive but joins combat the following turn, obeying any and all mental or spoken commands from the Uvinnik)

The battlefield grows colder than a blizzard, everyone within 30 feet of the Uvinnik must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or suffer {@dice 2d6} cold damage or have their speed is reduced by 10, the Uvinnik's choice.
The blacked heavy fog rises, making the battlefield heavily obscured for the round.

regionalEffects: A region containing the Uvinnik's lair is warped by the creature's forsaken presence, which creates the following effect:

items: The Uvinnik forces the weather in a 6-mile radius centered on its lair to be a constant blizzard. The effect is identical to the {@spell control weather} spell.

regionalEffects: If the Uvinnik is destroyed, these regional effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: Ii'Tliish
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the Ii'Tliish takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the Ii'Tliish can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: A dust devil appears on a point the Ii'Tliish can see within 120 feet of it, creating a 10 foot radius wide miniature tornado. Each creature in the dust devil's area must make a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be thrown 30 feet into the air.
The sand storm intensifies around the Ii'Tliish. The battlefield within 60 feet of the Ii'Tliish is considered to be heavily obscured. It lasts until initiative 20 on the next round.

The whipping winds around the Ii'Tliish flow through in a concentrated blast. Any creatures within 60 feet of the Ii'Tliish must succeed a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

regionalEffects: The region containing the Ii'Tliish's lair is warped by its very presence, which creates the following effects:

items: The area within 200 miles of it's nest, is slowly terraformed into a sprawling desert and Mesa basin.
All Elementals within that 200 miles have their intelligence and charisma reduced to 1, can't leave the area, and obey the Ii'Tliish's mental commands.
All desert animals within that 200 miles with an intelligence of 2 or lower are charmed by it, and are hostile to any intruders.

regionalEffects: If the Ii'Tliish dies, these effects fade over a period of {@dice 1d10} years.

feat.name: Dragon Discharge
entries: You have gained higher control of your elemental core. You gain the following benefits:

items: Your are able to control your breath in short bursts, which you can use as a ranged natural weapon. This weapon has a range of 30 feet, uses your Constitution or Charisma modifier (your choice) for it's attack and damage rolls, and deals {@dice 2d6} damage, the damage type determined by your ancestry.
You can use your Charisma modifier instead of Constitution when calculating the DC for your Breath Weapon racial trait.

feat.name: Fiendish Escape
entries: You sometimes leave fire in your wake, especially in dangerous situations. You gain the following benefits:

items: Whenver you take the {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage} action, you leave a trail of fire behind you. This fire lasts until the beginning of your next turn. A creature takes fire damage equal to your proficiency modifier when it enters the trail's area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there.

subclassFeature.name: Time Domain
entries: Deities that can influence the flow of time are few and far between in the Forgotten Realms, as 'time' is a great, universal constant that mortals can only begin to grasp. Clerics that worship a such a deity can, if only for a brief instant, channel their divine powers to stop their enemies in stasis and grant their allies an amazing alacrity.
At each indicated cleric level, add the listed spells to your spells prepared. They do not count towards your limit.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency with martial weapons.

subclassFeature.name: Glimpse of the Future
entries: From 1st level, your prayer gives you a glimpse of the future, allowing you to forsee certain events. You cannot be surprised as long as you are conscious, and you add your Wisdom modifier to your initiative rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Time Alter: Delayment
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to delay the actions of others.

As a reaction to a creature taking an action or bonus action within 15 feet of you, you can cause that action to happen at the end of your next turn or until your concentration ends (as if you were concentrating on a spell).

subclassFeature.name: Time Alter: Rollback
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can expend a use of your Channel Divinity to bring back a part of your power. As a bonus action, you touch your holy symbol, utter a prayer, and regain a spell slot you expended on this turn. The spell slot regained cannot be higher than a 5th-level spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon strikes with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {@dice 1d8} radiant damage to the target. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to {@dice 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Time Alter: Elongate
entries: At 17th level, you are gifted with the power to become a constant in time. As an action, you can cause a loop in time that constantly rewinds your body's metabolism and aging.

Ending the effect can be done with an action, however, the flow of time corrects itself immediately, and any time that passed during the rewind hits you at once. While the effect is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: You do not need to eat, drink or breathe.
You do not age, and can't be aged magically.

subclassFeature.name: Time Alter: Predict
entries: Also at 17th level, you can cast the {@spell Foresight} spell once per long rest.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered young until they reach the age of 50. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most dwarves are lawful, believing firmly in the benefits of a well-ordered society. They tend toward good as well, with a strong sense of fair play and a belief that everyone deserves to share in the benefits of a just order.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Traveler's Step
entries: Your base walking speed is 35 ft., however wearing heavy armor will reduce your speed to 25 ft.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer|phb}.

entries.name: Trade Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item Cartographer's Tools|phb}, Land Vehicles, or {@item Painter's Supplies|phb}.

entries.name: Expert Cunning (The Art of Bullshittery)
entries: You gain proficiency in {@skill Persuasion}, {@skill Performance}, or {@skill Deception}

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Dwarvish. Dwarvish is full of hard consonants and guttural sounds, and those characteristics spill over into whatever other language a dwarf might speak.

entries.name: Well Travelled
entries: You gain an additional language proficiency of your choice.

entries.name: A Society of Backpackers
entries: Travelers, merchants, and storytellers there are many professions a dwarf may pick up when they leave the underground and choose to live life above it all. Road dwarves have abandoned the smithing and stonecutting techniques of their subterran bretheren but make up for it in skills that help their new trades.

entries.name: Above Ground Dwarven Culture
entries: Dwarven Culture is almost always tied to heritage, whose house is in control of what branch of dwarven society. Living in mountains and beneath the earth is almost second nature to dwarves, so where do road dwarves fit into this? Road dwarves are the revels, the rogues, people who wanted to see more of the world and move away from the deadlocked ideals of tradition. Road dwarves literally take to the road, finding their way along the path as travelers. Many take the chance to become merchants seeking fortune, others begin caravan companies, and even more become wanderlust adventurers.

entries.name: Oh To Be a Road Dwarf
entries: Spotting a dwarf without armor above ground means you have most likely run into a road dwarf, they have long since abandoned smithing as a profession (though some may choose to relearn) and mostly prefer lighter clothing and weaponry to accomodate their vagabond lifestyles. Their time travelling have put a much lighter step in their heels and thus road dwarves whether on cart, mount, or foot seem to move about much more quickly and frequently than the average dwarf. Being more open to new things means it's not uncommon to spot a road dwarf bard recounting their adventures in a tavern or a master marksman and their trusty heavy crossbow.

Kingdoms rich in ancient grandeur, halls carved into the roots of mountains, the echoing of picks and hammers in deep mines and blazing forges, a commitment to clan and tradition, and a burning hatred of goblins and orcs-these common threads unite all dwarves.

entries.name: Short and Stout
entries: Bold and hardy, dwarves are known as skilled warriors, miners, and workers of stone and metal. Though they stand well under 5 feet tall, dwarves are so broad and compact that they can weigh as much as a human standing nearly two feet taller. Their courage and endurance are also easily a match for any of the larger folk.
Dwarven skin ranges from deep brown to a paler hue tinged with red, but the most common shades are light brown or deep tan, like certain tones of earth.
Their hair, worn long but in simple styles, is usually black, gray, or brown, though paler dwarves often have red hair. Male dwarves value their beards highly and groom them carefully.

entries.name: Long Memory, Long Grudges
entries: Dwarves can live to be more than 400 years old, so the oldest living dwarves often remember a very different world. For example, some of the oldest dwarves living in Citadel Felbarr (in the world of the Forgotten Realms) can recall the day, more than three centuries ago, when orcs conquered the fortress and drove them into an exile that lasted over 250 years. This longevity grants them a perspective on the world that shorter-lived races such as humans and halflings lack.

Dwarves are solid and enduring like the mountains they love, weathering the passage of centuries with stoic endurance and little change. They respect the traditions of their clans, tracing their ancestry back to the founding of their most ancient strongholds in the youth of the world, and don't abandon those traditions lightly. Part of those traditions is devotion to the gods of the dwarves, who uphold the dwarven ideals of industrious labor, skill in battle, and devotion to the forge.

Individual dwarves are determined and loyal, true to their word and decisive in action, sometimes to the point of stubbornness. Many dwarves have a strong sense of justice, and they are slow to forget wrongs they have suffered. A wrong done to one dwarf is a wrong done to the dwarf's entire clan, so what begins as one dwarf's hunt for vengeance can become a full-blown clan feud.

entries.name: Clans and Kingdoms
entries: Dwarven kingdoms stretch deep beneath the mountains where the dwarves mine gems and precious metals and forge items of wonder. They love the beauty and artistry of precious metals and fine jewelry, and in some dwarves this love festers into avarice. Whatever wealth they can't find in their mountains, they gain through trade. They dislike boats, so enterprising humans and halflings frequently handle trade in dwarven goods along water routes. Trustworthy members of other races are welcome in dwarf settlements, though some areas are off limits even to them.

The chief unit of dwarven society is the clan, and dwarves highly value social standing. Even dwarves who live far from their own kingdoms cherish their clan identities and affiliations, recognize related dwarves, and invoke their ancestors' names in oaths and curses. To be clanless is the worst fate that can befall a dwarf.
Dwarves in other lands are typically artisans, especially weaponsmiths, armorers, and jewelers. Some become mercenaries or bodyguards, highly sought after for their courage and loyalty.

entries.name: Gods, Gold, and Clan
entries: Dwarves who take up the adventuring life might be motivated by a desire for treasure-for its own sake, for a specific purpose, or even out of an altruistic desire to help others. Other dwarves are driven by the command or inspiration of a deity, a direct calling or simply a desire to bring glory to one of the dwarf gods. Clan and ancestry are also important motivators. A dwarf might seek to restore a clan's lost honor, avenge an ancient wrong the clan suffered, or earn a new place within the clan after having been exiled. Or a dwarf might search for the axe wielded by a mighty ancestor, lost on the field of battle centuries ago.

entries.name: Slow to Trust
entries: Dwarves get along passably well with most other races. "The difference between an acquaintance and a friend is about a hundred years," is a dwarf saying that might be hyperbole, but certainly points to how difficult it can be for a member of a short-lived race like humans to earn a dwarf's trust.

entries.name: Elves
entries: "It's not wise to depend on the elves. No telling what an elf will do next; when the hammer meets the orc's head, they're as apt to start singing as to pull out a sword. They're flighty and frivolous. Two things to be said for them, though: They don't have many smiths, but the ones they have do very fine work. And when orcs or goblins come streaming down out of the mountains, an elf's good to have at your back. Not as good as a dwarf, maybe, but no doubt they hate the orcs as much as we do."

entries.name: Halflings
entries: "Sure, they're pleasant folk. But show me a halfling hero. An empire, a triumphant army. Even a treasure for the ages made by halfling hands. Nothing. How can you take them seriously?"

entries.name: Humans
entries: "You take the time to get to know a human, and by then the human's on her deathbed. If you're lucky, she's got kin-a daughter or granddaughter, maybe-who's got hands and heart as good as hers. That's when you can make a human friend. And watch them go!. They set their hearts on something, they'll get it whether it's a dragon's hoard or an empire's throne. You have to admire that kind of dedication, even if it gets them in trouble more often than not."

entries.name: Dwarf Names
entries: A dwarf's name is granted by a clan elder, in accordance with tradition. Every proper dwarven name has been used and reused down through the generations. A dwarf's name belongs to the clan, not to the individual.
A dwarf who misuses or brings shame to a clan name is stripped of the name and forbidden by law to use any dwarven name in its place.

entries.name: Duergar
entries: In cities deep in the Underdark live the duergar, or gray dwarves. These vicious, stealthy slave traders raid the surface world for captives, then sell their prey to the other races of the Underdark. They have innate magical abilities to become invisible and to temporarily grow to giant size.

item.name: Eyes of Various Lenses
entries: These leather-framed goggles feature multiple, multicolored lenses. While wearing the goggles, you gain the following properties:

items: You have advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) to reveal information about an object you can see, and Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) and Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.
You can make out details of even extremely intricate objects up close, or extremely distant creatures and objects as small as 2 feet across.
You can cast the {@spell identify} spell using the goggles. Once you do so, you can't do so again until the next dawn.
